@ibddoctor It’s just a link in the menu bar of a bookdown that takes you to the relevant GitHub page so you can make quick edits or others can suggest edits via fork and pull request (all online).

In case anyone else (or future me) finds it difficult to figure out the edit button in #rstats bookdown, in _output.yml:

bookdown::gitbook:
  config:
    edit: "https ://github.com/{your}/{repo}/edit/main/%s"

(remove the space after https added so twitter doesn't mangle links)

TIL that if you use glue on textInput, it can execute arbitrary code!

input$name = "print('hacked!'); Lisa"

output$greet = renderText({
  glue("Hello {input$name}")
})

#> [1] "hacked!"
#> Hello Lisa

@BayesicTony @kareem_carr I think you’re right, but it affects how I’d explain it and how many steps it takes.

@kareem_carr The last two hints mean there’s a 0, but not in place 3.
So the 3rd hint means it must be in place 1.
6 can’t be the other number because hints 1 & 2 couldn’t both be right, so it’s 2.
Hint 1 means 2 is in place 3.
And if 6 can’t be in it, then hint 2 means 4 is in place 2. https://t.co/FZxbB0AiYI

@cconrymurray I made you a wee gist to explain what I mean. It's is a simpler design with 2Wx2B where 2 values must be >0 and two not > 0 to support the hypothesis. The individual test alpha you need to achieve a false positive rate of 0.05 is around 0.5!
https://t.co/a14RTknC0U https://t.co/h9kxSpq26A

@cconrymurray This is where simulation really shines. If you have rules like your theory is supported if a & c > x, and b & d !> x, then it’s best to run a simulation and see what alpha you need to use to determine if each single value is > x to have the overall false positive rate you want.

@cconrymurray That sounds like an ideal solution. And add a detailed explanation of your decision rules. It’s a pet peeve of mine when you can’t tell for sure what potential patterns of results would support, refute, or be uninformative to a theory.

@mjskay @AKatossky I want *really* simple examples that I don’t have to run myself, but can look at the inputs and outputs to see what the function does.

Too many functions have no examples or such convoluted examples that a beginner will have a hard time understanding them.

@cconrymurray Is your hypothesis supported only if all 3 are > 3.5? Then you definitely shouldn’t correct p-values.  

If it’s supported if any is > 3.5 and only 1/3 is sig, you should correct the p-value by dividing by the number of tests that could have supported the hypothesis (3).

@cconrymurray I’m not sure what you mean by only 3 are expected to be above 3.5. Do you mean the hypothesis only predicts those 3 will be > 3.5? Or that 3 of them happen to be < 3.5 but you would have concluded support of one of them had actually been significantly > 3.5?

@cconrymurray Is there a hypothesis that you’ll conclude support for if at least 1 of the 6 values is > 3.5? In which case, yes, you need corrections. I like Holmes corrections rather than bonferroni, but they’re the same in this case.

@cconrymurray Why are you testing 6 if you only care about 3 of them? What decision are you making if *any* of them are significant? If you don’t have a hypothesis and it’s exploratory, what do you need p-values for?

The big assessment for Level 1 is an R Markdown registered report using real, messy data that focuses on data wrangling, distributions, and visualisation. Students will care more about reproducibility if they are assessed on it. https://t.co/waMkM1et3U
Small-stakes assessments get students used to R Markdown and how code is structured. We mark them semi-automatically using @dalejbarr's assessr package https://t.co/VBNsk6fzXw https://t.co/qC1B6O6XIx

At @UofGPsychology we focus on data instead of inferential statistics in the first year. Although we have a 4-year degree, the slower start allows students to really take off in year 2 and fill all BPS requirements plus much more. https://t.co/3x84kzbMq3

Students have a knowledge and skills gap around structuring, transforming and visualizing data. These activities are time consuming, complex, and error-prone, yet many programmes give almost no instruction and only give students sanitized data sets.

The #psyTeachR philosophy:

* tidyverse first
* reproducible documents with R Markdown
* use real, messy data
* emphasise core data wrangling skills
* retrieval practice with {webex} questions
* live coding and walk-through videos

The history of #rstats at @UofGPsychology 

* 2010-11: MSc course taught in R, L3 students given a choice
* 2015-16: First staff training
* 2017-18: Full switch to R for all data and stats courses
* Yearly: staff training offered

@ajwills72 made a great point I'd never thought about before. Writing learning materials for a GUI-based program is a nightmare to upkeep!
Plymouth uses a self-hosted RStudio server to make sure all students can access R (e.g., tablets can't install R) and packages are kept up to date.

Training staff before you start transitioning students to R is important. @ajwills72 recommends developing written materials with a small number of competent (and enthusiatic) staff. Their materials are available open source at https://t.co/Oy9YH6oP3g

@dougaparry @ProfAndyField @jamovistats Other reasons are that if your end goal is R, two transitions will be harder than 1, and that JASP's EU funding future isn't certain, so it is much more likely to stop being supported than R.

@dougaparry @ProfAndyField @jamovistats We're also discussing that in the chat. Several reasons, but the most important for me is that R is better for data wrangling, which is a huge part of real analysis, but usually overlooked in undergrad courses.

#rstats is a practical skill, best learned by doing

* Lots of practice on few techniques 
* Build confidence by fading support
* Breadth through optionality

https://t.co/Oy9YH6oP3g

Why teach R?

1. They like it (at east they don't have it)
2. SPSS is in decline
3. It's free
4. Never out of date
5. Great at pre-processing (90% of analysis)
6. Accurate (unlike Excel)
7. Reproducible
8. Open source (catch those 🐞)
9. Works in a web browser (lower support 💰)

@ProfAndyField's ammunition for convincing your department to teach R.

TIL in #rstats:

You can show a verbatim inline R expression like this:
Use this code to add: `` `r knitr::inline_expr("1+1")` ``

And your document will display:
Use this code to add: `r 1+1`

Instead of:
Use this code to show: 2

So useful for #psyTeachR teaching resources!

I woke up this morning with “This horse isn’t from here, Abby / you can’t be callin’ me a lair” playing in my head. It was a sign! (That there would be a new @lubalin_vibe_co video, not that I’m pregante.) https://t.co/1hGBJYr6w4

But I hate when you try to find out what R code is doing and end up down a rabbit hole of 20 three-line functions that basically just call another function. (Or method; why is it so hard in R to find out what methods do!)

I also have a hard time finding the right balance between short, simple functions and not too many functions. I often try to cram a lot of options into one function that might be better as multiple functions. Which also violates the principle from before of having <3 arguments.

I also fall prey to the urge to replace five lines of expressive code with a single line of succinct but obscure code. Although I maintain that it’s worth learning when apply and map functions in R have advantages over for loops and using them enough that they aren’t obscure.

I have a hard time with expressive code. While I’m first writing code, short variable names seem perfectly understandable, but I know they’ll be opaque the next time I look at that code. And my comments are either overboard with redundant detail or missing entirely.
No duplication is hard to teach until students experience the pain of changing their mind about the value of a parameter that is scattered around the script and failing to find all its instances.

I totally agree with the idea expressed on this chapter that writing tests helps you write better functions. If it’s too complicated to test a function, or small changes break all your tests, the function should probably be broken up.

Kent Beck’s four rules of simple design:

1. Runs all the tests
2. Contains no duplication
3. Expresses the programmer’s intent
4. Minimises classes and methods

If you want to test this, make a demo app. Put this as the first line of app.R:
message("app")

Add a file R/test.R with just the code:
message("why are you running?")

When you run the app, you'll see the messages in the console. The files in R run before any code in app.R

For anyone who uses #rstats googlesheets4: are there ever cases where you *want* a column to have mixed character and numeric types, expressed as a column of 1-item lists, instead of coercing the column to a compatible type? https://t.co/P5puuC5Rb0

Instead, I've made a new function to append data to a google sheet. It handles data in a different order, missing columns, new columns, and columns with a different data type. It appends unless there is a new column, in which case it overwrites the sheet.

https://t.co/f8nSoAXuJj

So now I need to decide whether to use sheet_append in shiny apps and remember that this will cause lots of errors during development, or use read_sheet > bind_rows > write_sheet and risk simultaneous access problems.

Putting this into practice today, I quickly learned that googlesheets4 does *NOT* append data like dplyr::bind_rows 😖

id <- write_sheet(data.frame(first = 1, second = 2))
sheet_append(id, data.frame(second = 2, first = 1))
read_sheet(id)

# first second
# 1      2
# 2      1 https://t.co/tcraPZtsbv
@StuartJRitchie Do you think the big difference is gamers who catch a fraud gain clout, while scientists who catch a fraud often lose reputation?
@thuyvytnguyen And even if you’re averaging a lot of Likert ratings, your distribution will be truncated normal, which might cause problems if there is substantial skew. https://t.co/Swn7UrtDbu

@thuyvytnguyen It’s a disadvantage. You can often get away with a linear model if the Likert scale has 7 or more points and the distribution isn’t too skewed. But a DV with 3-5 levels almost definitely needs an ordinal model.

@thuyvytnguyen A huge disadvantage of Likert scales is analysis. Depending on your design, you might find the best analysis an ordinal mixed regression, which takes forever to run and isn't very intuitive to interpret. I find binomial models so much easier. So consider your analysis plan, too.

@SeveriLuoto @FredrikHedenus @DegenRolf For example if people in country A have on average higher DT scores and *also* more out LGB people than country B, even if LGB people have lower DT in both countries, an aggregated analysis might conclude the opposite if Na >> Nb for LGB subjects and Na~Nb for hetero subjects.

@SeveriLuoto @FredrikHedenus @DegenRolf Nope. If there are regional differences in both sexual orientation (e.g. likelihood of IDing as gay or bi) and dark triad traits, you can end up with a different or even opposite relationship within countries to what you see for the aggregated data.

FIRST rules for unit tests:

🏃‍♀️Fast: so you run them frequently
🔀Independent: run in any order
🔁Repeatable: don’t need a certain environment (like a network connection)
✅Self-Validating: don’t require you to check logs or visual output
⏱Timely: written before production code
@bmwiernik I guess then the test you write before you add a new function fails because that function doesn’t exist? https://t.co/eyjyLN9UlM

Is TDD mainly applicable to working on well-established code? Or is it something you could implement to develop a new R package from scratch, or even an analysis script? I’m keen to incorporate more unit tests in one-off scripts, but not sure how to go about it.

In practice, I imagine this looks like:

1. Identify what you want your code to do 
2. write a test that shows your current code doesn’t do it
3. Write code to make the test pass

Which makes sense if the thing is “handle numeric input to x()” but not if it’s “run a new analysis”

I’m a little embarrassed that I never really understood Test Driven Development until now. 

The three laws of TDD: https://t.co/BX2HxLtzkt

For R code, the threshold for doing this isn’t always clear. Sometimes I’ll wrap summary(lmer_mod) in my own function because it’s used 20 times in a script and I’ll probably want to clean up the summary display later. But it can’t be efficient to wrap all functions in your own!

Wrapping 3rd party code in your own code has saved me so much time. I don’t remember why, but I originally wrote my own function for MySQL queries for the precursor to Experimentum, and when PHP 5.0 deprecated mysql_* functions, it was a few lines to change instead of thousands.

Continuing my 🧵 on Clean Code (which I’m reading while eating lunch in the park because the Glasgow ☀️ is glorious)

I love the idea of “learning tests” where you write unit tests while learning 3rd party packages to test your understanding and quickly catch if updates bork it.
